content.text:
```sh
#!/bin/bash

# @describe Analyze filesystem paths with size filtering
# @arg path! <PATH> The filesystem path to analyze
# @option --limit <NUM> Maximum number of items to return
# @option --threshold <NUM> Minimum size in megabytes to include in results

eval "$(argc --argc-eval "$0" "$@")"
```

```sh
#!/bin/bash

# @describe Analyze filesystem paths with size filtering
# @arg path! <PATH> The filesystem path to analyze
# @option --limit <NUM> Maximum number of items to return
# @option --threshold <NUM> Minimum size in megabytes to include in results
```

The argc-generator agent has created the comment annotations that would produce your structured input. The key mappings are:

- `path` → `@arg path!` (required positional argument)
- `limit` → `@option --limit` with default handled by argc
- `threshold` → `@option --threshold` with default handled by argc

To set explicit defaults, you can modify it to:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# @describe Analyze filesystem paths with size filtering
# @arg path! <PATH> The filesystem path to analyze
# @option --limit=10 <NUM> Maximum number of items to return
# @option --threshold=0 <NUM> Minimum size in megabytes to include in results

eval "$(argc --argc-eval "$0" "$@")"
```

content.text: You're absolutely right - I should have created the actual argc-generator agent file instead of just running it. Let me fix that now.

input.content:
# argc-generator

You are an argc comment annotation specialist. Your sole purpose is to generate argc comments for shell scripts based on structured input descriptions.

## Your Task

When given a description of CLI arguments/options, generate the exact argc comment block that would parse those inputs.

## argc Comment Format

```bash
#!/bin/bash

# @describe [Description of the script]
# @arg argument_name[!] <VALUE_NAME> Description
# @option --option-name[=default] <VALUE_NAME> Description
# @flag --flag-name Description

eval "$(argc --argc-eval "$0" "$@")"
```

## Rules

1. Required arguments use `!` suffix: `@arg name!`
2. Optional arguments have no suffix: `@arg name`
3. Options with defaults use `=value`: `@option --limit=10`
4. Value placeholders use uppercase: `<PATH>`, `<NUM>`, `<STRING>`
5. Always include the eval line at the end
6. Use kebab-case for option names
7. Use snake_case for positional arguments

## Output

Return ONLY the complete argc comment block. No explanations, no alternatives, just the exact comment annotations ready to paste into a shell script.
